price_objection.objection: This is too expensive / I can find it cheaper online
price_objection.underlying_emotion: Fear of waste if project fails, budget guilt, comparison anxiety
price_objection.authentic_response: You're right that online might be cheaper per item, but here's what you're getting: you can see and touch the quality before buying, start your project today instead of waiting for shipping, and if you grab the wrong thing, we'll exchange it - no return shipping hassle. Plus, our staff actually uses these supplies and can help you avoid expensive mistakes.
price_objection.reframe: Cost per successful project, not cost per item
price_objection.when_to_concede: If customer clearly just price shopping and not valuing service, let them go gracefully and invite them back when they need help

supply_hoarding_guilt.objection: I already have too many supplies at home / I need to use what I have first
supply_hoarding_guilt.underlying_emotion: Guilt over unused supplies, partner judgment, financial responsibility concerns
supply_hoarding_guilt.authentic_response: That's actually really responsible thinking. What if we focus just on what you need to complete one specific project? Sometimes finishing something feels better than starting new. Or, if you're excited about something new, what if this is the 'use it or lose it' motivation to finally tackle those UFOs (unfinished objects)?
supply_hoarding_guilt.reframe: Completing projects requires the right supplies, not just any supplies
supply_hoarding_guilt.when_to_concede: Respect the boundary and offer organization solutions or project-specific shopping lists for later

skill_level_fear.objection: This looks too hard for me / I'm not good enough to use this
skill_level_fear.underlying_emotion: Fear of failure, imposter syndrome, wasting money on unused supplies
skill_level_fear.authentic_response: I totally get that fear - but here's the thing: this technique looks harder than it is, and we have [beginner-friendly version] that gives you similar results while you learn. Also, we do workshops where you can try before investing in all the supplies. Want me to show you the beginner approach?
skill_level_fear.reframe: Every expert was once a beginner with the same fears
skill_level_fear.when_to_concede: If genuinely too advanced, redirect to appropriate skill level with encouragement about working up to it

time_scarcity.objection: I don't have time to craft / This will just sit there unfinished
time_scarcity.underlying_emotion: Overwhelm, guilt about self-care, fear of adding to UFO pile
time_scarcity.authentic_response: What if we think about this differently - not as adding another big project, but as having supplies ready for when you do have 20 minutes? Some of our customers keep quick projects by the TV for commercial breaks or while kids are doing homework. It's not all-or-nothing.
time_scarcity.reframe: Having supplies ready enables spontaneous creative moments
time_scarcity.when_to_concede: Acknowledge their reality and suggest coming back when life calms down

decision_paralysis.objection: There are too many options / I don't know which one to choose
decision_paralysis.underlying_emotion: Fear of choosing wrong, perfectionism, analysis paralysis
decision_paralysis.authentic_response: Let me narrow it down for you based on your project. For what you're making, these three options would all work great. Here's the difference: [A] is most economical, [B] is easiest for beginners, [C] gives the most professional finish. Which matters most for this project?
decision_paralysis.reframe: Most choices are good choices - perfect is the enemy of done
decision_paralysis.when_to_concede: Offer to hold items while they think, or suggest starting with smallest commitment

quality_skepticism.objection: Is this actually good quality or just expensive?
quality_skepticism.underlying_emotion: Distrust of marketing, past disappointments, value consciousness
quality_skepticism.authentic_response: Great question - I actually use this myself for [specific projects]. Here's the honest difference between this and the budget version: [specific functional differences]. For your project, [recommendation based on their actual needs]. Sometimes the expensive one isn't necessary.
quality_skepticism.reframe: Honest guidance builds trust more than upselling
quality_skepticism.when_to_concede: If budget version truly works for their needs, recommend it confidently

trend_fatigue.objection: This is just a trend / I'll never use this again
trend_fatigue.underlying_emotion: Waste aversion, trend exhaustion, desire for timeless skills
trend_fatigue.authentic_response: You might be right that [specific trend] will fade, but the techniques you learn transfer to other projects. trend_fatigue.when_to_concede: Validate their preference for classic techniques and redirect to timeless supplies

6/ Buying cheap tools, expensive materials. Should be reversed. Good tools last forever. Materials get used up. Invest in quality scissors, brushes, needles.

thread_structure: Craft store employee here. We're trained to upsell you things you don't need. Here are the 5 tactics we use (and how to avoid falling for them) 🧵
1/ The 'Project Bundle' trap. We suggest buying everything for a complete project. Sounds helpful, right? You probably have 40% of it at home already.
2/ 'You'll need this too' add-ons. Buying paint? We'll suggest 3 types of brushes, sealer, primer. You might only need 1 brush. Ask: 'What's absolutely essential?'
3/ Premium product pushing. We're taught to show expensive options first. Always ask: 'What's the difference between this and your cheapest option?'
4/ The scarcity play. 'This is our last one' or 'This sale ends today.' Check online. It's probably available elsewhere or on sale again next month.
5/ Cross-category suggestions. Buying yarn? We'll show you crochet hooks, patterns, stitch markers. Only buy what you need for your current project.
Pro tip: Make a list before you come in. Stick to it. We're trained to create 'inspiration' that leads to impulse buys.
Not saying don't buy from craft stores (I work at one!). Just be aware of the tactics. Your wallet will thank you.
